intro: Vigna sublobata, commonly known as the mountain cowpea, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a legume belonging to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and small, pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is well adapted to high-altitude environments. Its seeds are edible and have been traditionally used by indigenous communities for food and medicinal purposes. Vigna sublobata is also valued for its ability to fix nitrogen in the soil, making it an important plant in sustainable agriculture.
